pli-tv-bu-vb-pc66:1.6: Pajānāth’āvuso, lit. “You know, friends.” According to the commentary to the Dīgha Nikāya, DN-a.2.436: Tvaṁ pajānāhīti tvaṁ jāna. Sace gaṇhitukāmosi, gaṇhāhīti vuttaṁ hoti, “Tvaṁ pajānāhi: you know. If you wish to take it, please do: this is what is meant.” In other words, it’s up to you to do what you like.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc66:2.1.6: The meaning of the last of these three ways of knowing, so vā āroceti, is not clear. The Critical Pali Dictionary suggests: “sa (sā) āroceti (?). Perhaps this last form is conformable to sa. Sanskrit] ārocayate med. caus. [middle voice causative] in the meaning: he or she makes inquiries (of others).” However, this does not fit with the parallel usage at bhikkhu-pācittiya 29 [Bu Pc 29:3.1.6 where the text says that she tells (sā vā āroceti) him, presumably referring to the nun telling the monk. In this case āroceti cannot refer to the monk making inquiries. The commentaries are silent, and I therefore assume that a straightforward meaning is the most likely one. I would suggest, then, that it refers to the group of travelers (i.e. the thieves or one of them) telling the monk directly.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc66:2.1.15: For addhayojana, “half a yojana”, see essay on Measures.
